message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and risk factors (smoking, sexually active) suggest that the most likely cause is Intraductal papilloma, a benign breast tumor. Subareolar ultrasound can help detect the presence of papillomas. Image-guided core biopsy is invasive and not necessary yet. Nipple discharge cytology is not a preferred initial approach. Reassurance is not appropriate until a cause is identified.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest that further imaging is necessary to evaluate for any underlying pathology. Ultrasound is simple and non-invasive and can help identify any underlying mass or ductal dilation. Image-guided biopsy or nipple discharge cytology can be done if the ultrasound is abnormal, but they are more invasive and pose some risk of complications. Reassurance may be appropriate for benign causes, but further evaluation is needed in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a possible intraductal papilloma or other benign breast lesion. Subareolar ultrasound is the most appropriate initial imaging study. Image-guided core biopsy may be needed if the ultrasound reveals a suspicious lesion. Nipple discharge cytology is less likely to identify the cause of the symptoms in this case. Reassurance should only be offered after a more definitive diagnostic evaluation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with blood-tinged nipple discharge, which can indicate intraductal papilloma or breast cancer. Subareolar ultrasound can help to visualize any mass or lesion in the duct. Image-guided core biopsy or nipple discharge cytology can also be done, but ultrasound is the first choice according to the American Society of Breast Surgeons. Reassurance is not a suitable option as further investigation is needed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most appropriate next step in management would be subareolar ultrasound to look for any ductal dilatation or mass. Image-guided core biopsy would be the next step if there is an abnormality seen on the ultrasound. Nipple discharge cytology can be considered but it may not be diagnostic. Reassurance is not appropriate without further investigation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits a bloody nipple discharge, which is usually caused by intraductal papilloma or breast cancer. Subareolar ultrasound is the most appropriate next step in management, as it can help identify any abnormalities in the duct. Image-guided core biopsy or nipple discharge cytology may be needed if the ultrasound shows any suspicious findings. Reassurance is not appropriate without further investigation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest intraductal papilloma or nipple discharge, which can be confirmed or ruled out by a subareolar ultrasound. Image-guided core biopsy can be done if needed, but it is not the first step in management. Nipple discharge cytology is not as accurate as imaging. Reassurance is not appropriate until a diagnosis is confirmed or ruled out.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptom and risk factors make it necessary to rule out potential breast cancer. Subareolar ultrasound is a non-invasive method to detect abnormal findings in the mammary ducts, and can help to determine if a biopsy is necessary. Image-guided core biopsy or nipple discharge cytology may follow if necessary, but subareolar ultrasound is the first step in the management of the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s age and history of recent menstruation suggests that the most likely cause of nipple discharge is a benign intraductal papilloma. Subareolar ultrasound is the most appropriate next step in management to identify any structural abnormalities that may be causing the nipple discharge. Image-guided core biopsy or nipple discharge cytology may be done if structural abnormalities are found on the ultrasound. Reassurance alone is not appropriate without further investigation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and physical examination are suggestive of intraductal papilloma or duct ectasia. Subareolar ultrasound is the most appropriate next step in management to evaluate the breast tissue and ducts. Image-guided core biopsy is generally not necessary unless cancer is suspected. Nipple discharge cytology may not provide sufficient information to address the underlying cause. Reassurance should only be given after a proper evaluation of the cause of the nipple discharge.
